canonical_explanation.text: A figure has line symmetry if a line can divide it into two identical halves that are mirror images of each other. This line is called the line of symmetry (or axis of symmetry). A figure may have no line of symmetry, exactly one, or multiple lines of symmetry. A regular polygon with n sides has exactly n lines of symmetry. A circle has infinitely many lines of symmetry.
rules: Rule 1: A line of symmetry divides a figure into two mirror-image halves that overlap exactly when folded along that line.
Rule 2: A regular polygon with n sides has exactly n lines of symmetry (equilateral triangle = 3, square = 4, regular pentagon = 5, regular hexagon = 6).
Rule 3: A rectangle has 2 lines of symmetry; an isosceles triangle has 1; a scalene triangle has 0.
Rule 4: Capital English letters with vertical line symmetry include A, H, I, M, O, T, U, V, W, X, Y. Letters with horizontal line symmetry include B, C, D, E, H, I, K, O, X.
Rule 5: A circle has infinitely many lines of symmetry — every diameter is a line of symmetry.

questions.question_text: A figure has line symmetry if:

options.text: A line divides it into two mirror-image halves
It can rotate and look the same

questions.explanation_correct: A figure has line symmetry when a line (called the line of symmetry) divides it into two halves that are exact mirror images of each other.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Line symmetry means a line can divide the figure into two identical mirror halves. Having four sides, rotating, or having curved edges are not the definition of line symmetry.

questions.question_text: Another name for a line of symmetry is:
questions.explanation_correct: A line of symmetry is also called an axis of symmetry.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A diagonal joins two non-adjacent vertices. A median joins a vertex to the midpoint of the opposite side. An altitude is perpendicular to the opposite side. The correct term is axis of symmetry.

questions.question_text: If you fold a figure along its line of symmetry, the two halves overlap exactly.
questions.explanation_correct: This is the defining property of a line of symmetry — folding along it makes both halves coincide perfectly.
questions.explanation_incorrect: By definition, folding a symmetric figure along its line of symmetry makes the two halves match exactly.

questions.question_text: Which of the following shapes has NO line of symmetry?
questions.explanation_correct: A scalene triangle has all three sides of different lengths and all three angles different, so it has no line of symmetry.
questions.explanation_incorrect: An equilateral triangle has 3, a square has 4, and a circle has infinitely many lines of symmetry. Only a scalene triangle has no line of symmetry.

questions.question_text: How many lines of symmetry does a circle have?
questions.explanation_correct: Every diameter of a circle is a line of symmetry, and there are infinitely many diameters, so a circle has infinitely many lines of symmetry.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A circle does not have a limited number of symmetry lines. Every line passing through the centre (i.e., every diameter) is a line of symmetry.

questions.question_text: An isosceles triangle has how many lines of symmetry?
questions.explanation_correct: An isosceles triangle has exactly 1 line of symmetry — the line from the vertex between the two equal sides to the midpoint of the unequal side.
questions.explanation_incorrect: An isosceles triangle has two equal sides, giving it exactly one line of symmetry (the perpendicular bisector of the base).

questions.question_text: A rectangle has exactly 4 lines of symmetry.
questions.explanation_correct: A rectangle (that is not a square) has exactly 2 lines of symmetry — one horizontal and one vertical through the centre. Its diagonals are NOT lines of symmetry.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A rectangle has only 2 lines of symmetry. The diagonals of a rectangle do not produce mirror-image halves (unless the rectangle is a square).

questions.question_text: How many lines of symmetry does an equilateral triangle have?
questions.explanation_correct: An equilateral triangle is a regular 3-sided polygon, so it has exactly 3 lines of symmetry — one from each vertex to the midpoint of the opposite side.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A regular polygon with n sides has n lines of symmetry. An equilateral triangle has 3 sides, so it has 3 lines of symmetry.

questions.question_text: How many lines of symmetry does a square have?
questions.explanation_correct: A square is a regular 4-sided polygon, so it has 4 lines of symmetry — two through midpoints of opposite sides and two along the diagonals.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A square has 4 lines of symmetry: 2 through midpoints of opposite sides (horizontal and vertical) and 2 along the diagonals.

questions.question_text: A regular hexagon has how many lines of symmetry?
questions.explanation_correct: A regular hexagon has 6 sides, so it has exactly 6 lines of symmetry.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A regular polygon with n sides has n lines of symmetry. A regular hexagon has 6 sides, so it has 6 lines of symmetry.

questions.question_text: A regular pentagon has ______ lines of symmetry.
questions.explanation_correct: A regular pentagon has 5 sides, so it has exactly 5 lines of symmetry.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A regular polygon with n sides has n lines of symmetry. A regular pentagon has 5 sides, so the answer is 5.

questions.question_text: A regular polygon with 8 sides (regular octagon) has how many lines of symmetry?
questions.explanation_correct: A regular octagon has 8 sides, so it has exactly 8 lines of symmetry.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A regular polygon with n sides has n lines of symmetry. A regular octagon has 8 sides, so it has 8 lines of symmetry.

questions.question_text: Which of these capital English letters has a vertical line of symmetry?
questions.explanation_correct: The letter A has a vertical line of symmetry — its left and right halves are mirror images.
questions.explanation_incorrect: F, G, and J do not have vertical symmetry. The letter A has a vertical line of symmetry dividing it into two mirror halves.

questions.question_text: Which of these capital English letters has a horizontal line of symmetry?
questions.explanation_correct: The letter B has a horizontal line of symmetry — the top half mirrors the bottom half.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A has vertical symmetry only. N and S do not have horizontal line symmetry. B has a horizontal line of symmetry.

questions.question_text: Which letter has both a horizontal and a vertical line of symmetry?
questions.explanation_correct: The letter H has both a horizontal and a vertical line of symmetry.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A and T have only a vertical line of symmetry. B has only a horizontal line of symmetry. H has both horizontal and vertical lines of symmetry.

questions.question_text: The digit 8 has a horizontal line of symmetry.
questions.explanation_correct: The digit 8 has a horizontal line of symmetry — the top half mirrors the bottom half.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The digit 8 does have a horizontal line of symmetry. When you draw a horizontal line through its middle, the top and bottom halves are mirror images.

questions.question_text: A figure and its mirror image are related by:
questions.explanation_correct: A mirror image is a reflection, which is the concept behind line symmetry. The mirror acts as the line of symmetry.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A mirror produces a reflection, which is line symmetry. Rotation turns a figure, translation slides it, and enlargement changes its size.

questions.question_text: Which everyday object typically has line symmetry?
questions.explanation_correct: Most leaves have an approximate line of symmetry along their central vein (midrib), dividing them into roughly mirror-image halves.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A crumpled paper, a handwritten letter, and an irregular rock generally do not have line symmetry. A typical leaf has approximate symmetry along its midrib.

questions.question_text: A rectangle has ______ line(s) of symmetry.
questions.explanation_correct: A rectangle has 2 lines of symmetry — one horizontal and one vertical, each passing through the centre.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A rectangle has exactly 2 lines of symmetry: one connecting the midpoints of the longer sides and one connecting the midpoints of the shorter sides.

questions.question_text: Which shape has exactly 1 line of symmetry?
questions.explanation_correct: An isosceles triangle has exactly 1 line of symmetry — the perpendicular from the vertex angle to the midpoint of the base.
questions.explanation_incorrect: An equilateral triangle has 3, a rectangle has 2, and a square has 4 lines of symmetry. An isosceles triangle has exactly 1.

questions.question_text: A kite-shaped figure has:
questions.explanation_correct: A kite has exactly 1 line of symmetry — the diagonal connecting the two vertices where unequal sides meet.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A kite (with two pairs of consecutive equal sides) has exactly 1 line of symmetry along its main diagonal.

questions.question_text: How many lines of symmetry does a rhombus (that is not a square) have?
questions.explanation_correct: A rhombus has 2 lines of symmetry — its two diagonals.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A rhombus has all sides equal and its diagonals bisect each other at right angles. Both diagonals are lines of symmetry, giving it exactly 2.

questions.question_text: A parallelogram (that is not a rectangle or rhombus) has how many lines of symmetry?
questions.explanation_correct: A general parallelogram has 0 lines of symmetry. Although opposite sides are parallel and equal, no line can divide it into two mirror-image halves.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A plain parallelogram (not a rectangle or rhombus) has no line of symmetry. Only special parallelograms like rectangles and rhombuses have lines of symmetry.

questions.question_text: A regular polygon has 10 lines of symmetry. How many sides does it have?
questions.explanation_correct: A regular polygon with n sides has exactly n lines of symmetry. So if it has 10 lines of symmetry, it has 10 sides (decagon).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Since a regular polygon with n sides has n lines of symmetry, 10 lines of symmetry means 10 sides.

questions.question_text: Which group of capital letters ALL have at least one line of symmetry?
questions.explanation_correct: A, M, T, and W all have a vertical line of symmetry.
questions.explanation_incorrect: F and G have no line of symmetry. N, S, Z have no line symmetry (they have rotational symmetry only). J and L have no symmetry. A, M, T, W all have vertical line symmetry.

questions.question_text: The digit 0 has how many lines of symmetry?
questions.explanation_correct: The digit 0 (when written as an oval/ellipse) has 2 lines of symmetry — one horizontal and one vertical.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The digit 0 written in standard form has both a horizontal and a vertical line of symmetry, giving it 2 lines of symmetry.

questions.question_text: A semicircle has how many lines of symmetry?
questions.explanation_correct: A semicircle has exactly 1 line of symmetry — the perpendicular bisector of its diameter (the vertical line through the centre).
questions.explanation_incorrect: A semicircle only has 1 line of symmetry along the perpendicular bisector of its straight edge (the diameter).

questions.question_text: Which of the following statements is TRUE?

options.text: A regular triangle has more lines of symmetry than a square
A square has more lines of symmetry than a regular hexagon
A regular hexagon has more lines of symmetry than a regular pentagon
A regular pentagon has more lines of symmetry than a regular hexagon

questions.explanation_correct: A regular hexagon has 6 lines of symmetry while a regular pentagon has 5, so the hexagon has more.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Equilateral triangle = 3, square = 4, regular pentagon = 5, regular hexagon = 6. The hexagon (6) has more than the pentagon (5).

questions.question_text: The letter N has a line of symmetry.
questions.explanation_correct: The letter N does not have any line of symmetry. It has rotational symmetry (180 degree rotation), but no line can divide it into mirror-image halves.
questions.explanation_incorrect: N has no line of symmetry. If you try any line through it, the two halves are not mirror images of each other.

questions.question_text: If a shape has a vertical line of symmetry, which statement is true about any point on the left side?

options.text: It has a corresponding point at the same distance to the right of the line
It has a corresponding point at double the distance to the right
It has a corresponding point directly above it

questions.explanation_correct: For any point on one side of a line of symmetry, there is a mirror point on the other side at the same perpendicular distance from the line.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Line symmetry means each point has a mirror image on the opposite side at the same distance from the line of symmetry.

questions.question_text: A regular polygon with 12 sides has ______ lines of symmetry.
questions.explanation_correct: A regular polygon with n sides has n lines of symmetry. So a regular 12-sided polygon (dodecagon) has 12 lines of symmetry.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A regular n-gon has exactly n lines of symmetry. For n = 12, the answer is 12.

questions.question_text: A butterfly is an example of symmetry in nature. Its line of symmetry is:
questions.explanation_correct: A butterfly has approximate bilateral (left-right) symmetry. The vertical line along its body divides it into two mirror-image halves.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A butterfly has a vertical line of symmetry along its body. The left wing mirrors the right wing.

questions.question_text: A right-angled isosceles triangle has how many lines of symmetry?
questions.explanation_correct: A right-angled isosceles triangle has 2 equal sides (the legs), so it is isosceles and has exactly 1 line of symmetry along the perpendicular bisector of the hypotenuse.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Since it is isosceles (two equal legs), it has 1 line of symmetry. Having a right angle does not give it additional symmetry lines.

questions.question_text: Which of the following digits has a vertical line of symmetry?
questions.explanation_correct: The digit 0 has a vertical line of symmetry (and a horizontal one too). The digits 2, 5, and 6 do not have a vertical line of symmetry.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Among the options, only the digit 0 has a vertical line of symmetry. Digits 2, 5, and 6 are not symmetric about a vertical line.

questions.question_text: An arrow pointing upward (like ↑) has:
questions.explanation_correct: An upward-pointing arrow has 1 vertical line of symmetry. The left and right halves are mirror images.
questions.explanation_incorrect: An arrow pointing up has a vertical line of symmetry. It does not have a horizontal line of symmetry because the top (pointed) and bottom (flat) are different.

questions.question_text: A regular polygon always has as many lines of symmetry as it has sides.
questions.explanation_correct: A regular polygon with n sides always has exactly n lines of symmetry.
questions.explanation_incorrect: This is a true statement. For any regular polygon, the number of lines of symmetry equals the number of sides.

questions.question_text: The word 'MOM' (in capital letters) has:

options.text: Both horizontal and vertical lines of symmetry

questions.explanation_correct: The word MOM has a vertical line of symmetry through the middle of the letter O. M and M mirror each other, and O itself is symmetric.
questions.explanation_incorrect: MOM reads the same when reflected about a vertical line through its centre. It does not have horizontal symmetry because M does not have horizontal symmetry.

questions.question_text: Riya says a trapezium always has at least one line of symmetry. Is she correct?

options.text: Yes, every trapezium has 1 line of symmetry
No, only an isosceles trapezium has a line of symmetry; a general trapezium has none
Yes, every trapezium has 2 lines of symmetry
No, no trapezium has any line of symmetry

questions.explanation_correct: Riya is incorrect. Only an isosceles trapezium (where the non-parallel sides are equal) has 1 line of symmetry. A general trapezium has 0 lines of symmetry.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A general trapezium has no line of symmetry. Only the special case of an isosceles trapezium has exactly 1 line of symmetry.

questions.question_text: Arrange these shapes in order of increasing number of lines of symmetry: equilateral triangle, circle, rectangle, square.
questions.explanation_correct: Rectangle = 2, equilateral triangle = 3, square = 4, circle = infinite. In increasing order: rectangle (2), equilateral triangle (3), square (4), circle (infinite).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Count the lines: rectangle = 2, equilateral triangle = 3, square = 4, circle = infinitely many. Increasing order is 2, 3, 4, infinity.

questions.question_text: A shape has exactly 2 lines of symmetry that are perpendicular to each other. Which of the following could it be?
questions.explanation_correct: A rectangle (that is not a square) has exactly 2 lines of symmetry — one horizontal and one vertical — and they are perpendicular to each other.
questions.explanation_incorrect: An equilateral triangle has 3 lines (not 2). A regular pentagon has 5. A scalene triangle has 0. Only a rectangle (not a square) has exactly 2 perpendicular lines of symmetry.

questions.question_text: If a regular polygon has the same number of lines of symmetry as a square, what shape is it?
questions.explanation_correct: A square has 4 lines of symmetry. The only regular polygon with exactly 4 lines of symmetry is one with 4 sides, which is a square.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A regular polygon with n lines of symmetry has n sides. Since a square has 4 lines of symmetry, only a regular 4-sided polygon (square) matches.

questions.question_text: How many capital English letters from A to Z have at least one line of symmetry?
questions.explanation_correct: The capital letters with at least one line of symmetry are: A, B, C, D, E, H, I, M, O, T, U, V, W, X — a total of 14.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Letters with line symmetry: A, B, C, D, E, H, I, M, O, T, U, V, W, X. That is 14 letters out of 26.

questions.question_text: Aman drew a figure with exactly 3 lines of symmetry. Which of the following could be his figure?
questions.explanation_correct: An equilateral triangle has exactly 3 lines of symmetry. A square has 4, a rectangle has 2, and an isosceles triangle has 1.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Square = 4, rectangle = 2, isosceles triangle = 1. Only an equilateral triangle has exactly 3 lines of symmetry.

questions.question_text: Which of the following has MORE lines of symmetry than a regular hexagon?
questions.explanation_correct: A regular hexagon has 6 lines of symmetry. A regular octagon has 8 lines of symmetry, which is more than 6.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Pentagon = 5, square = 4, equilateral triangle = 3, all less than hexagon's 6. A regular octagon has 8, which is more.

questions.question_text: The letter X has:
questions.explanation_correct: The letter X has 4 lines of symmetry: horizontal, vertical, and the two diagonals.
questions.explanation_incorrect: X is highly symmetric. It has 4 lines of symmetry — horizontal, vertical, and both diagonals — making it one of the most symmetric letters.

questions.question_text: Which statement about lines of symmetry is FALSE?

options.text: A circle has infinitely many lines of symmetry
A square has exactly 4 lines of symmetry
Every quadrilateral has at least one line of symmetry
A scalene triangle has no line of symmetry

questions.explanation_correct: Not every quadrilateral has a line of symmetry. A general parallelogram (not a rectangle or rhombus) and a general quadrilateral with all different sides have no line of symmetry.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A, B, and D are all true. C is false because many quadrilaterals (like a general parallelogram) have no line of symmetry.

questions.question_text: A shape has 5 equal sides and 5 equal angles. How many lines of symmetry does it have?
questions.explanation_correct: A shape with 5 equal sides and 5 equal angles is a regular pentagon, which has exactly 5 lines of symmetry.
questions.explanation_incorrect: This describes a regular pentagon (5 equal sides, 5 equal angles). A regular n-gon has n lines of symmetry, so a regular pentagon has 5.

questions.question_text: Which of the following words (in capitals) has a horizontal line of symmetry?
questions.explanation_correct: DECIDED — each letter D, E, C, I, D, E, D has a horizontal line of symmetry. So the entire word has a horizontal line of symmetry.
questions.explanation_incorrect: In MATH, A does not have horizontal symmetry. In BOOK, B and K have horizontal symmetry but O has both, and together the word does not work because of letter arrangement. DECIDED has all letters (D, E, C, I, D, E, D) with horizontal line symmetry.

questions.question_text: A regular polygon has more than 4 but fewer than 7 lines of symmetry. Which polygon could it be?
questions.explanation_correct: More than 4 and fewer than 7 means 5 or 6 lines of symmetry. A regular pentagon has 5 and a regular hexagon has 6.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The number of lines of symmetry must be 5 or 6 (more than 4 and fewer than 7). Regular pentagon = 5, regular hexagon = 6. Both fit.

questions.question_text: Priya claims that the number of lines of symmetry of a regular polygon is always equal to twice the number of its sides. Is she correct?

options.text: No, it is equal to the number of its sides
No, it is equal to half the number of its sides
No, it depends on the specific polygon

questions.explanation_correct: Priya is wrong. A regular polygon with n sides has exactly n lines of symmetry, not 2n.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The rule is: a regular n-sided polygon has exactly n lines of symmetry. Not twice, not half — exactly n.
